div1.head: Recollections of the Yellow Fever Commission, by Jefferson Randolph Kean, May 25, 1946

head.hi: QUESTIONS FOR GENERAL KEAN PREPARED APRIL, 1946

item.p:
Question #1: Comments on remarks of Dr. L. O. Howard published in his
“History of Applied Entymology” 1930.

Your comments in regard to the quotation are entirely in accord with
my impressions on the subject. I cannot furnish any authoritative veri-
fication, however. I doubtless told you that Howard gave Reed some
Lazear
instructions on mosquitoes before Reed and Howard went to Cuba. This is
in accordance with what I understood from Reed. I have no recollection
of Carroll being included.

list.item:
Question #2: What Lazear's reasons were for joining the Medical De-
partment, I do not know. If it was to do any special work, and if the
intention came from higher authority, it should have come to me because
I was the Chief Surgeon under whom he worked. I had made requests for
a laboratory man to be sent for service in my department, and understood
that Lazear was the man.

Question #3: I think that you are right in thinking that Lazear first
met Reed when Reed came to Cuba to investigate electrozone. I have a
strong impression however that Professor Welch of Johns Hopkins had re-
commended Lazear to Reed as a man who knew about mosquitoes. We all
knew, some years before, about the use of kerosene to fight mosquitoes
from Howard's publications (Key West). I recommended it to the town
authorities in Key West when I was post-Surgeon there about 1895-

Question #4: I have no means of knowing who initiated the formation
of the Yellow Fever Commission. It was, however, a matter that pertained
to the Surgeon General and not to Reed. I think the credit under Army
rules would belong to the Chief. He would naturally consult Reed, how-
ever, so as to get men who were personae gratae to him.

Question #5: I am inclined to agree with Truby that Reed may have se-
lected Lazear on Professor Welch's recommendation. As to Agramonte,
I think that the Surgeon General would have been more likely to think
of him as he was a laboratory man and was already on duty in that work
in Cuba. Carroll was already Reed's handy man in the laboratory. Reed
had trained him.

Question #6: I had never heard, until you wrote me of it, that the
words “especially yellow fever” were omitted from the order creating the
Yellow Fever Board. Your guess is as good as mine as to the reason for
omitting it.

Question #7: I do not know why Lazear went to Cuba via Tampa. I think,
however, that the line of big steamers from New York to Havana was
established after Lazear arrived in Cuba. I think that the Morro Castle
Ward Liner was one of the first of these fine new boats, and its first trip was
after February 1900. It is, however, I think a matter of no importance.

Question #8: I doubt whether the passenger lists of the Army transports
in those years would be now available. They would be buried under the
accumulated records of the last World War. Below is a list of Reed's
comings and goings as shown in my diaries:
May 4, Reed> 1900 lunched with me. Investigated typhoid outbreak in
Puerto Principe - Diary Vol 4. p 113
Comes to investigate Electrozone Plant, March 10, 1900 diary IV. p. 160
Returns to U.S.... ... no record - Probably about April first-
Arrived with Carroll Yellow Fever Board, June 25 1900
Reed goes to Washington, Typhoid Report, Aug. 2, 1900
Reed returns to Havana, October 4, 1900
We go to see General Wood, October 12.
- 3 -
Reed goes to Washington, October 13, 1900
He returns to Havana, October 28 (Diary p. 191)
He returns to Wash. finally, Feb. 9, 1901 (7 to 10)
Diary IV P. 116 saw Reed's report on Puerto Principe 1899
Wrote Reed about typhoid at camp (p. 119) 1899-
(Y.F. Diary pp 128-133-135-138-Reed to Manila p. 140 Kanned 1899 did not go)
O'Reilly goes to U.S. 11th Nov. P. 143
Y.F. Diary IV P. 145
We moved into General Lee's house Maceo St. P. 147
Reed to Manila P. 149
Gen. Wood arrived in Cuba to command it, Dec. 23, 1899
Reed came March 10 and came to lunch with me on 11th (see also
p. 161
(See order for Gorgas and me p. 164)
Y.F. 166, 168, 169, 172
Question #9: I have not a copy of the photograph of Reed, but as
officers did not travel in uniform in time of peace, I would certainly
accept Blossom's statement in the matter.
Question #10: I have no recollection of when I heard of the formation
of the Yellow Fever Board. It would doubtless have struck me as a
natural and appropriate thing to do.
Question #11: It was obvious to me that the work of the Yellow Fever
Board should be a secret. By making it so they avoided all sorts of
vexatious interruptions. It was entirely within the authority of the
Commanding Officer at Columbia Barracks to order them all off the mili-
tary reservation at Columbia Barracks if he knew that they were ex-
perimenting with yellow fever. His authority to do this would never
be contested by anybody in the Army at that time.
- 4 -
Question #12: Knowing the character of the Commanding Officer of
Columbia Barracks as I did, I think that he would not have hesitated for
one instant to disregard any orders and wishes of the Surgeon General
in any sanitary matter. I have not at hand my interview of May 8, page
7 marked “Confidential” so that I do not remember what I said and so
cannot amplify.
Question #13: I did not know that the Finca San Jose had been visited
by Finlay until I read it in his son's book. It is certainly a very
interesting coincidence.
Question #14: The interview of Kean and Reed with General Wood occured
in General Wood's office, which was in the first story above the ground
floor at the front of the Palacio looking out on the square. There
were, as I recollect, four 6 large rooms, possibly six8, in the front which
faced north, and General Wood's office was in the second from the right
of these rooms. The two windows of that room looked out on the Palace
and the entrance to the harbor, and as I recollect, Morro Castle in the
distance. This is the picture which I have in mind.
Question #15: It would be difficult for me to designate except in a
general way the space where was located the Detention camp for the Span-
ish immigrants who poured into Cuba in 1900. There is, or used to be,
a large level area to the east and south of the Cabaña fortress. It
was under the service of the Marine Quarantine, which was under a man
named Manocal, and he did business with the U.S. Quarantine service
and was I think desirous to comply with their wishes in every respect.
I never visited this camp. Whether Major Reed went over there to get
his Spanish volunteers I do not know, but I think he did business with
- 5 -
Manacol about getting them. He employed them for general labor, and
made his proposal later at Camp Lazear. about the experiments
QUESTION #16: I have no direct knowledge as to how Reed established
contacts with his Spanish volunteers or what the “certain” difficulties
were. Probably Agramonte helped him in this.
Question #17: I do not think that you could find out anything about
the interview of the Spanish Consul General in Havana and Major Reed on
the subject of these experiments by contacting the Spanish Legation in
Cuba now. I called him a “very nice man” because he was courteous and
sympathetic with Reed. I never knew him and do not remember his name.
Question #18: The idea that Dr. Lazear was so reticent about the char-
acter of his investigation on account of his having insurance was not
my guess. I think I got the idea from Reed, but if Mrs. Lazear said
he had no insurance I think that settles it. I think that Lazear was
naturally a very self-contained, reserved man.
Question #19: You ask where are the survivors of Carter, Gorgas, Stern-
berg, General Lister and Neate. They are all five dead. The only one
who has a descendant, as far as I know, is General Gorgas, whose daughter
married a sanitary engineer named Wrightson. They are living somewhere
near Washington, and I had a long talk with her when I was presented
with the Gorgas Medal some years ago. She is a fine woman. Her name is
Aileen
Dr. Henry R. Carter's daughter, Laura A. Carter, married Admiral
Stitt retired Surgeon General of the Navy - his second wife. She died
some years ago without issue.
Question #20: I wish I could give you some details about Major Reed's
visit to me when I was sick with yellow fever on June 25, 1900. My
mind, however, is quite blank about the incidents of my illness.
- 6 -
Whether it was an effect of the disease or not, I do not know, but I
simply remember that he came and stood by my bed and said a few words
to me. He was probably told not to make a long visit because I do not
remember him as sitting down. I cannot repeat any word of the conver-
sation. I do not think I knew when Reed was expected, or if he would
come to see me.
Question #21: I have no recollection of knowing Agramonte before the
formation of the Yellow Fever Board. I used to call on Lazear to go
with me to see fever cases because he was familiar with the symptoms
of the various fevers and could examine the blood for malaria. I
remember well his showing me how to recognize the male and female
stegomyia mosquitoes when we visited the yellow fever cases at 102
Calsada Real and other cases in Marianao. Lazear recognized the
stegomyia (the common house mosquito of Cuba) but at that time did not
know it was the carrier of yellow fever.
Question #22: I had no official connection with the yellow fever com-
mission until September 1900 when General Wood turned over to me the
money which he gave Major Reed for the purposes of his commission. He
did that, as he told Major Reed, because I was a permanent officer of
his staff and knew how to account for Cuban funds. How the money
should be spent was left entirely to our discretion. I had never at
any time any suggestion that I should help Reed or the Board in any
way, and it is certain that none was necessary. My good friend and
Commanding Officer, General Fitzhugh Lee, once advised me not to be
too enthusiastic about Reed's findings because he had observed that
all discoveries about yellow fever were soon afterwards disproved, and
he feared my reputation would be injured if I were identified with the
findings of the Reed Board. I told him that I was perfectly willing
to risk my professional reputation upon their accuracy.
- 7 -
Question # 23: I know nothing about the planning of Camp Lazear.
Reed knew what he wanted and drew his own plans. I do not imagine that
they were copied in any way from those of the Italian students of
malaria.
Question #24: My attitude towards Reed's plans were entirely voluntary
and with enthusiasm.
Question #25: I was deeply distressed over Lazear's death. It happened
that I was away on an inspection trip with the chief surgeon, Colonel
Havard during the period of his illness. I got back to Columbia Barracks
only a few days before his death, and as I found out from Dr. Ames that
he was very ill, I never saw him. I do not understand the question
“Did Kean suspect that Lazear's death was unusual”. There is certainly
nothing unusual about such a termination in a severe case of yellow
fever.
Question #26: I see no reason why you should hesitate to tell the
facts about Dr. Godfrey's failure to meet his professional obligations
at Pinar del Rio. Whether it is necessary to mention his name, I can-
not say. It might be a certain protection to his assistants to do so.
Question #27: The instructions regarding yellow fever which Godfrey
ignoried were sent out from time to time by the Chief Surgeon in Havana
and by the Chief Surgeon in Marianao. They were explicit and in my
inspection of the hospitals I usually inquired as to whether they were
carried out in all cases of fever. I will enclose one which I think I
can put my hand on. I gave you one-
Question #28: As to the room that Reed died in, I think you will be
safe to follow Truby's sketch. I recall when I visited him when he
was dying and took Blossom down to see him that I went up a flight of
- 8 -
stairs and the room was on the left. The south side as I recollect-
Question #29 & 30: It never occurred to me that Moran's feelings would
be hurt by the honors paid to Kissinger. When Moran declined the
gratuity of $200 which I offered him, I thought it settled the matter
and that he was content. With Kissinger, I was not so sure and when
I offered to give him a watch and chain from the gratuity he was
much pleased. He afterwards asked me if there was any balance, and
when I told him “yes” he said he would be glad to have it. It was,
I think, $40.00 or $50.00. The watch was presented to him and his
promotion to Acting Hospital Steward was announced to show the ap-
preciation of the medical officers for the gallantry shown by men
of the hospital corps in submitting to these experiments.
The ceremony was probably in the last ten days of January 1901.
It is my recollection that Colonel Havard was present and made a few
remarks, but they were, I am sure, quite extemporaneous and were not
made of record. There would have been no point that I can see in
inviting Moran to this little ceremony.
Question #31: Your guess is as good as mine as to why a picture was
pasted over the old framed Benigno contract. My idea is that it
was to conceal its identity so that it could not be found when looked
for and it would have been easy to carry it off later.
Question #32: It was simply about the odd ideas that dear old Dr.
Finlay got when he became senile. Gorgas told me this story, and I
will tell it to you when I see you. It is of no importance.
Question #33: No.
- 9 -
Question #34: I cannot amplify the statement about Reed's vexation
that Carroll after being inoculated by a yellow fever mosquito should
have gone to Havana, and of all places to Agramonte's laboratory
where he was conducting an autopsy, during the period of incubation.
Of course it destroyed the value of Carroll's case as an experiment.
Whether Reed said anything to Carroll about it, I do not know. The
damage had been done and Carroll was still sick. He expressed himself
to me as being much disgusted with Carroll. Whether it was on the
transport at Matanzas or when he came to see me later at Marianao,
I am not quite certain.
Question #35: I cannot give you any data about the camp for Spanish
non-immune immigrants at Cabanao.
Question #36: The Gorgas-Guiteras yellow fever experiments which
resulted so disastrously occurred long after Reed had finished his
yellow fever work and left Cuba. They occurred in Aug. 1901. Carroll
told me about them when Reed sent him down to Cuba to make tests of
filtered yellow fever blood to determine whether the cause of the in-
fection was bacterial or a virus. They were so much rattled over
these deaths that they would not allow Carroll to take blood from any
of their experimental yellow fever cases. He told me about it when
he came to lunch at my house about August 16th. I can give you the
dates of the deaths of these cases if you want them. They were re-
ported I think in Dr. Finlay's annual report. The American nurse,
Miss Maas was the last one to die on August 23. I never heard Reed
say anything about these cases.
Question #37: I do not know anything about the Roll of Honor file
kept by General Reynolds. The official Roll of Honor file is pub-
- 10 -
lished every year in the Army Register. I can give you a copy of the
official file if you want it.
Question #38: I do not know anything about Reed having said that he
wished Pinto had a mild attack. I think that must be Truby's story.
Question #39: Mrs. Lazear's story is very nice and I see no reason
why it should not be accepted. I have very vague recollections about
Mrs. Lazear's coming to Cuba.
Question #40: Well what about it?
Question #41: I am sorry that no one wrote to Mrs. Lazear after her
husband's death. I think Truby, who was his Commanding Officer, should
have done it.
Question #42: I would be glad to see the editorial on aviation
(Harboard's article) I read it
Question #43: As regards Carroll's promotion to Major, it must have
been by a special act of Congress - I do not recall.
Question #44: I will try to find Reed's letter of July 1900. I have
not been able to find any of Reed's letters in the search I am now mak-
ing. (I showed you what I had when you were here)
Question #45: Reed told me, as I recall, in a quizzical way that he
was puzzled over the report of XY's case. It was important to show
that he had been under quarantine during the period of incubation,
but if he gave his name and company, he was afraid he would get into
trouble with the Commanding Officer. I am not very certain what I
told him, but I think it was that line officers do not read medical
reports and by the time it got around to the Commanding Officer, if
it ever did, it would be too late to do anything about it. It was
- 11 -
not an Infantry Captain who complained through channels about one of
his men, but an Artillery Officer stationed at Santa Clara Battery.
I do not think Colonel Baldwin ever heard of this incident.
Question #46: No one accompanied Kean and Reed on their visit to
General Wood on October 12th.
Question #47: Truby has told the story substantially, as I recall
it, in his book. Why don't you stick to that?
Question #48: Truby knows more about this than anyone else. Why
don't you accept his story which is substantial, as I recall it?
Question #49: I do not think I can shed any light on the story of
Lazear's so-called accidental inoculation in Las Animas.
Question #50: As you know, Colonel Gorgas remained in Cuba after
General Wood and the American forces and government left Cuba on the
2nd of May 1902. I presume that Gorgas had some sort of trouble over the
disinfection of clothing coming from Havana to the United States. He
probably let the old regulation continue in operation in spite of the
action of the military authorities as to the disinfection of fomites
being unnecessary. I remember that Reed told me here in Washington
that he had written a letter of congratulation to Gorgas when Gorgas
had reported to him that he had ceased to disinfect fomites in Havana.
It may be that the Public Health Service has some record of when dis-
infection of clothing (yellow fever) stopped in Havana. They had
supervision over this matter.
Some file
Question #51: I think that I heard Gorgas' expression of Finlay's
“wonderful scientific clairvoyance” used in his talking to me about
Finlay. It may, however, behave been used in his article on “Warfare Against
- 12 -
Mosquitoes”. I will look and see. The S. Y. asked Gorgas to write
this article-
Question #52: I think it is perfectly obvious that Gorgas could not
ask for a volunteer majority to be given to a man on duty in Washing-
ton. It would certainly be less questioned if the man was at that
time on duty in Cuba. The U.S. Volunteers were authorized for
service abroad-
Question #53: The general reaction was to accept the danger of yel-
low fever as one of the incidents of the service. This was the atti-
tude of medical officers as far as I saw them. It was the business of
the officers to avoid infection and they did so as far as they could.
There was no panic at any time although most of the officers sent
their families north.
Question #54: I do not know in what building in Havana the Pan
American Medical Congress met. Much to my disappointment I was sent
to Washington for examination for promotion just at that time and
never attended the congress.
Question #55: I never have seen Dr. Guiteras' speech at the Finlay
dinner in print. A year or two ago Dr. Francisco Dominguez sent me
his book written in French and published in Paris- “The Centenary of
Dr. Finlay.” He describes that dinner quite fully, but states that he
got up the dinner at the request of General Wood and ran things gener-
ally. I do not think he mentions Dr. Guiteras. I know he does not
mention me although I was sitting next to Dr. Finlay, and I have no
remarkrecollection of meeting him at the dinner. It is a curious example of how
differently two persons recollect the same event after forty years.
Question #56: The idea of testing petroleum oils of various densi-
ties with respect to their power to kill mosquito larvae was my own.
I do not know of any other experiments that were conducted about it.
I satisfied myself that the heavier oils did not spread over the
- 13 -
surface of the water rapidly enough to be efficient. My objective
was to be able to answer any questions of my examining board on that
subject.
Question #57: I do not know what has become of the various letters
I had from Walter Reed. I will look again before you get here.
Question #58: There is no difference between an Assistant Surgeon
General and a Deputy Surgeon General. It is probable that the latter
term was used in Secretary Root's act reorganizing the Army.
Question #59: I have found one letter from you written from New
Orleans not long ago which I will give you when you come in June.
Question #60: The bound volume of addresses, articles etc. relating
to Cuba in which the speech of Dr. Lopez del Valle was printed is at
the Alderman Library, University of Virginia. When you go to see your
brother there, go to Dr. Harry Clemons, the Librarian, and ask for it;
he will find it for you.
Question #61: I will look again for the packet of letters of Guiteras.
Finlay etc.
Question #62: No, I do not want any more copies of Hygiea with your
fine article and the picture. I think that Mrs. Kean has sent one to
every one of her friends or mine.
Question #63: (a) I will try to find that letter
(b) Both refer to the same letter
(c) I destroyed that as Ireland thought it would
not give a correct idea of Reed.
Question #64: I will get your longhand letters for you.

div1.p: These I gave you in June
